definition[0]: giving a lot of attention to something because you want to find out more about it or because you enjoy it
example[0]: I wasn’t sure if he was really interested or if he was just being polite.
example[1]: I’d be very interested to hear your opinion.
example[2]: I’ve always been interested in music.
example[3]: All she’s interested in is clothes.
definition[1]: if you are interested in doing or having something, you want to do it or have it
example[4]: I’ve got a spare ticket for the opera, if you’re interested.
example[5]: Sheila’s interested in starting her own business.
example[6]: Would you be interested in a second-hand car?
explanation[1]: You are interested in doing something
example[8]: Are you interested in working abroad?
bad_example[1]: Are you interested to work abroad?
explanation[2]: You say that you would be hear/know/see/find out something  Don’t use  with other verbs such as ‘have’ or ‘buy’
example[9]: I would be interested to know what she thinks about the idea
definition[2]: giving your attention to something because you want to know more about it or you enjoy it
example[10]: Recently I’ve got very interested in photography.
definition[3]: very interested by something you see, read, or hear about
example[11]: She watched, fascinated, as the bird came closer until she could almost touch it.
example[12]: The more I read about the place, the more fascinated I became.
definition[4]: wanting to find out more information about something
example[14]: I was curious to find out the reasons for his sudden departure.
definition[5]: interested in something because it seems strange or mysterious
example[15]: He was intrigued by her story.
definition[6]: used when talking about the kind of things you are interested in and enjoy doing
example[17]: I got into  (=became interested in) yoga when I was at college.
heading[1]: so interested that you give something all your attention
definition[7]: very interested in something, so that you give it all your attention and do not notice anything else
example[18]: Jane was lying on the sofa engrossed in a novel.
example[19]: She was so absorbed in her own thoughts that she didn’t hear me call.
definition[8]: very interested, especially in a story you are reading, a film you are watching etc, so that you are eager to find out what happens next
example[20]: It was a brilliant book and I was gripped from beginning to end.
example[21]: I was so riveted by the film that I forgot the time.
definition[9]: very interested and enjoying something very much, so that you want to see or hear more
example[22]: From the opening line of the play, the audience was completely enthralled.
definition[10]: extremely interested in something very strange or wonderful, so that you are unable to move or think of anything else
example[23]: He could hold audiences spellbound with the power of his voice.
definition[11]: showing by your expression that you are very interested in something and are giving all your attention to it
example[25]: He spoke before a rapt audience.
example[26]: The congregation listened with rapt attention.
definition[12]: to be extremely interested in what someone is telling you
example[27]: Tell me exactly what happened. I’m all ears.
definition[13]: not wanting to know about something or give it your attention
example[28]: I just wasn’t at all interested in science at school.
definition[14]: not interested in wanting to know about something, especially something you are told
example[29]: When I tried to tell her about my holiday, she seemed completely uninterested.
definition[15]: not interested in a particular problem or situation, so that you are not willing to make an effort to change and improve things
definition[16]: having no interest in someone or something, and often not caring about them
example[31]: Sometimes the government seems indifferent to the problems of the poor.
definition[17]: used when saying that someone does not care at all about something and is not interested in it
example[32]: I couldn’t care less what other people think.
